ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: We looked at the Aztecs (aka the Mexica), the Romans, and the Ottoman Turks, and then did a comparative analysis of the United States and the current international system.Good amount of reading, reading responses every 3-4 weeks, but it's interesting if you're into this kind of stuff.

It's a great class, especially if you are interested in the topics of primacy, unipolarity or historical empires. Its a great view and critique of many traditional IR theories and a solid choice for anyone interested in international relation
It's ok. Reading list seems interesting but is too much and kocher isn't super fun to be in a classroom with for 2 hours.

Exactly as advertised. A shit-ton of reading, but you don't totally need to do all of it. Prof Kocher is a somewhat dominating figure in the discussion, which has both its benefits and its drawbacks (he WILL hold students accountable, which I love, but if he doesn't agree with something, he may also dwell on it for a long time...), and, as he admitted on the first day, no, even he has not read many of the books - meaning they are unpredictably hit or miss....Your call... I thought it was OK, but each class was either great or painful, depending on the quality of the book being discussed, and how well my classmates prepared.
I had a great time in this class. A lot of reading but very worthwhile.
